A Theoretical Framework for Grokking: Interpolation followed by Riemannian Norm Minimisation

Etienne Boursier
INRIA
LMO, Université Paris-Saclay
Orsay, France
etienne.boursier@inria.fr
&Scott Pesme
INRIA
Grenoble, France
scott.pesme@inria.fr
&Radu-Alexandru Dragomir
Télécom Paris
Institut Polytechnique de Paris
Palaiseau, France
dragomir@telecom-paris.fr
Abstract

We study the dynamics of gradient flow with small weight decay on general training losses F:ℝd→ℝ:𝐹→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝF:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_F : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R. Under mild regularity assumptions and assuming convergence of the unregularised gradient flow, we show that the trajectory with weight decay λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ exhibits a two-phase behaviour as λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\to 0italic_λ → 0. During the initial fast phase, the trajectory follows the unregularised gradient flow and converges to a manifold of critical points of F𝐹Fitalic_F. Then, at time of order 1/λ1𝜆1/\lambda1 / italic_λ, the trajectory enters a slow drift phase and follows a Riemannian gradient flow minimising the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm of the parameters. This purely optimisation-based phenomenon offers a natural explanation for the grokking effect observed in deep learning, where the training loss rapidly reaches zero while the test loss plateaus for an extended period before suddenly improving. We argue that this generalisation jump can be attributed to the slow norm reduction induced by weight decay, as explained by our analysis. We validate this mechanism empirically on several synthetic regression tasks.

1 Introduction

Strikingly simple algorithms such as gradient methods are a driving force behind the success of deep learning. Nonetheless, their remarkable performance remains mysterious, and a full theoretical understanding is lacking. In particular: (i) convergence to low training loss solutions on non-convex objectives is far from trivial, and (ii) it is unclear why the resulting solutions generalise well (Zhang et al., 2017). These questions are accompanied by a range of surprising phenomena that arise during training. One such intriguing behaviour is known as the grokking phenomenon, which we explore in this work. Coined by Power et al. (2022), this term describes a two-phase pattern in the learning curves: first, the training loss rapidly decreases to zero, while the test loss plateaus at a certain value. This is followed by a second phase, where the training loss remains zero, but the test loss steadily decreases, leading to a final improved generalisation performance, as depicted in Figure 1 (left).

In this paper, we propose a novel theoretical perspective to explain this phenomenon. By examining the gradient flow dynamics with weight decay, we show that, in the limit of vanishing weight decay, we can fully describe the trajectory of the model parameters. Specifically, we prove that the training process can be decomposed into two distinct phases. In the first phase, the gradient flow follows the unregularised path, converging to a manifold of critical points of the training loss. In the second, the trajectory enters a slow drift phase, where the weights move along this manifold, driven by weight decay, gradually reducing their ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm, as illustrated in Figure 1 (right). We argue that this slow decrease in the weight norms explains the grokking phenomenon, as smaller weight norms are often correlated with better generalisation. To convey the main intuition, we state below an informal version of our result, describing the full trajectory of the gradient flow with small weight decay.

Informal statement of the result.

For a generic training loss F:ℝd→ℝ:𝐹→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝF:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_F : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R satisfying some regularity assumptions, we consider the gradient flow wλsuperscript𝑤𝜆w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT regularised with weight decay: w˙λ⁢(t)=−∇F⁢(wλ⁢(t))−λ⁢wλ⁢(t)superscript˙𝑤𝜆𝑡∇𝐹superscript𝑤𝜆𝑡𝜆superscript𝑤𝜆𝑡\dot{w}^{\lambda}(t)=-\nabla F(w^{\lambda}(t))-\lambda w^{\lambda}(t)over˙ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = - ∇ italic_F ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) - italic_λ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ). Under the assumption that the unregularised gradient flow trajectory is bounded, we prove the following.

Theorem 1 (Main result, informal).

As the weight decay parameter λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ is taken to 00, the trajectory wλ⁢(t)superscript𝑤𝜆𝑡w^{\lambda}(t)italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) can be seen as a composition of two coupled dynamics:

  1. 1.

    (Fast dynamics driven by F given by Proposition 1) In a first phase, the weights follow the unregularised gradient flow and converge to a manifold of critical points of F𝐹Fitalic_F.

  2. 2.

    (Slow dynamics driven by the weight decay given by Proposition 2) At time t≈1/λ𝑡1𝜆t\approx 1/\lambdaitalic_t ≈ 1 / italic_λ, the iterates start slowly drifting along this manifold, following a Riemannian gradient flow that decreases the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm of the weights.

Link with the grokking phenomenon.

Note this is a purely optimisation result: no statistical assumptions are made, and it a priori does not imply any improvement in test loss during the slow phase. However, it provides a natural explanation for the grokking phenomenon. Indeed, in practice, for many deep learning models with random initialisation, gradient flow converges to a global minimiser of the training loss. When this solution generalises poorly—as is often the case with large initial weights, in the so-called lazy regime (Chizat et al., 2019)—the subsequent slow drift along the critical manifold, driven by weight decay, decreases the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm of the solution and simplifies it in the second phase. Since lower weight norms often correlate with better generalisation (Bach, 2017; Liu et al., 2022c; D’Angelo et al., 2024), this offers a convincing explanation for the delayed improvement in test performance. We discuss various settings where this behaviour is observed in Section 5.

2 Related work

Grokking in experimental works.

The term grokking was originally coined by Power et al. (2022), which studied a two-layer transformer trained with weight decay on a modular addition task. They observed that the network quickly fits the training data while generalising poorly, followed much later by a sudden transition to near-perfect generalisation. Following this work, many studies have investigated modular addition tasks to better understand the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon (Nanda et al., 2023; Gromov, 2023). However, grokking has been observed far beyond this setting. For instance, Barak et al. (2022) showed that training a neural network to learn parities exhibits a similar delayed generalisation pattern. In Liu et al. (2022c), grokking was induced across a broad range of tasks, including image classification and sentiment analysis, by using small datasets, large initialisations, and weight decay. Other settings and architectures where grokking-like behaviour appears include matrix factorisation (Lyu et al., 2023) and learning XOR-clustered data with a ReLU network (Xu et al., 2023). Finally, it is worth noting that this delayed transition in generalisation was already observed in earlier works, as clearly illustrated in Figure 3 of Chizat and Bach (2020).

Grokking as the transition between lazy and rich regimes.

Several works have framed grokking as the transition between the lazy and rich regimes. The lazy regime, also called the NTK regime, was introduced by Jacot et al. (2018). It typically arises when the network is trained from large initialisations (Chizat et al., 2019), and corresponds to a setting where zero training loss can be quickly achieved, but often with poor generalisation performance. In contrast, the rich regime (also called the feature learning regime) corresponds to a setting where the network actively learns new internal features during training. In the classification setting, Lyu and Li (2019) show that the rich regime is always attained for homogeneous parameterisations, and similarly, Chizat and Bach (2020) provide an analogous result for infinitely wide two-layer networks. In this context, Lyu et al. (2023) and Kumar et al. (2024), followed by Mohamadi et al. (2024), offer a theoretical perspective on grokking as the transition from the lazy regime to the rich regime during training: initially, the predictor quickly converges towards the NTK solution, and later escapes this regime to reach a better generalising solution, driven by the effects of implicit regularisation and/or weight decay.

The role of weight decay.

The role of weight decay in grokking remains somewhat debated. While many of the original works exhibiting the phenomenon include weight decay (Power et al., 2022; Liu et al., 2022b), grokking has also been observed without (Chizat and Bach, 2020; Xu et al., 2023), as strongly emphasised by Kumar et al. (2024). However, as shown in Lyu et al. (2023), the transition tends to occur much later and to be less sharp without weight decay. In this context, weight decay can be interpreted as a factor that triggers or accelerates the transition from the lazy to the rich regime. While grokking can be observed in classification tasks even without weight decay—thanks to the algorithm’s implicit bias—to the best of our knowledge, it cannot occur in regression tasks unless weight decay is used. Of particular relevance to our work, Liu et al. (2022c) propose an intuitive explanation of grokking that is based on weight decay: during the first phase, the model rapidly converges to a poor global minimum; during the second, slower phase, weight decay gradually steers the iterates toward a lower-norm solution with better generalisation properties. While appealing, this explanation remains informal and lacks rigorous theoretical support. In this work, we provide a formal analysis of the optimisation dynamics underlying the grokking phenomenon: an initial fast phase leads to convergence toward the solution associated with the lazy regime, followed by a slower second phase that drives convergence toward the solution characteristic of the rich regime.

Drift on the interpolation manifold.

Many theoretical works in the machine learning community have studied the training dynamics of gradient methods in overparameterised neural networks, where the set of zero training loss solutions forms a high-dimensional manifold. In this context, leveraging results from dynamical systems theory (Katzenberger, 1990), the work of Li et al. (2021) describes the drift dynamics induced by stochastic noise after stochastic gradient descent (SGD) reaches the manifold. This analysis was further extended by Shalova et al. (2024). Leveraging a similar stochastic differential framework, Vivien et al. (2022) precisely characterises this drift in the setting of diagonal linear networks, and proves that it leads to desirable sparsity guarantees. Much in the spirit of our work, although outside the deep learning context, Fatkullin et al. (2010) derive stochastic differential equations that describe the dynamics of systems with small random perturbations on energy landscapes with manifolds of minima, illustrating how the system first converges to the manifold and then drifts along it. Whereas these works emphasise drift induced by the stochasticity of gradient updates, our analysis focuses on a deterministic drift arising from the regularisation of the training objective.

3 Setting and preliminaries

We consider a loss function F:ℝd→ℝ+:𝐹→superscriptℝ𝑑subscriptℝF:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}_{+}italic_F : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which is sufficiently smooth, as stated in Assumption 1 below. Typical examples include the least square loss over some training dataset, where the parameters to optimise represent the weights of some neural network architecture. For a given λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0italic_λ > 0, we define the regularised loss Fλsubscript𝐹𝜆F_{\lambda}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as:

Fλ⁢(w)≔F⁢(w)+λ2⁢‖w‖22,∀w∈ℝd.formulae-sequence≔subscript𝐹𝜆𝑤𝐹𝑤𝜆2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑤22for-all𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑\displaystyle F_{\lambda}(w)\coloneqq F(w)+\frac{\lambda}{2}\|w\|_{2}^{2},% \qquad\forall w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) ≔ italic_F ( italic_w ) + divide start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∥ italic_w ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ∀ italic_w ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Initialising the parameters from w0∈ℝdsubscript𝑤0superscriptℝ𝑑w_{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (independently of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ), we then consider the gradient flow wλsuperscript𝑤𝜆w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over the regularised loss for any λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0italic_λ > 0, as the solution of the differential equation

w˙λ⁢(t)=−∇Fλ⁢(wλ⁢(t)) and wλ⁢(0)=w0.formulae-sequencesuperscript˙𝑤𝜆𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝜆superscript𝑤𝜆𝑡 and superscript𝑤𝜆0subscript𝑤0\begin{gathered}\dot{w}^{\lambda}(t)=-\nabla F_{\lambda}(w^{\lambda}(t))\quad% \text{ and }\quad w^{\lambda}(0)=w_{0}.\end{gathered}start_ROW start_CELL over˙ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = - ∇ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) and italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW (1)

Gradient flow is the limit dynamics of (stochastic) gradient descent as the learning rate goes to 0. For λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0italic_λ = 0, we denote wGFsuperscript𝑤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the gradient flow on the unregularised loss:

w˙GF⁢(t)=−∇F⁢(wGF⁢(t)) and wGF⁢(0)=w0.formulae-sequencesuperscript˙𝑤GF𝑡∇𝐹superscript𝑤GF𝑡 and superscript𝑤GF0subscript𝑤0\begin{gathered}\dot{w}^{\mathrm{GF}}(t)=-\nabla F(w^{\mathrm{GF}}(t))\quad% \text{ and }\quad w^{\mathrm{GF}}(0)=w_{0}.\end{gathered}start_ROW start_CELL over˙ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = - ∇ italic_F ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) and italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW (2)

In the remaining of the paper, we consider the following assumption on the objective function.

Assumption 1.

The function F𝐹Fitalic_F is 𝒞3superscript𝒞3\mathcal{C}^{3}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, its third derivative is locally Lipschitz and F𝐹Fitalic_F is definable in an o-minimal structure. Moreover, the solution wGFsuperscript𝑤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to the gradient flow ODE (2) is bounded.

The regularity conditions on F𝐹Fitalic_F ensure that, for any λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0italic_λ ≥ 0, the gradient flow ODE has a unique solution, which is defined for all t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0italic_t ≥ 0. This is a consequence of the Picard–Lindelöf theorem and boundedness of the trajectories. Definability in the o-minimal sense guarantees that bounded gradient flow trajectories converge to a limit point (Kurdyka, 1998, Thm. 2). This is a mild assumption satisfied by most functions arising in applications, such as polynomials, logarithms, exponentials, subanalytic functions, and finite combinations of those; see Coste (1999); Bolte et al. (2007) for more details. Finally, note that the boundedness assumption on the unregularised flow excludes classification settings where the network can perfectly separate the data, since in such cases the unregularised iterates diverge.

3.1 Stationary manifold and Riemannian flow

Assumption 1 guarantees that the gradient flow converges to a limit point w∞GF≔limt→∞wGF⁢(t)≔subscriptsuperscript𝑤GFsubscript→𝑡superscript𝑤GF𝑡w^{\mathrm{GF}}_{\infty}\coloneqq\lim_{t\to\infty}w^{\mathrm{GF}}(t)italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ), which is a stationary point of F𝐹Fitalic_F. In typical scenarios of training overparameterised models, stationary points are not isolated, but form continuous sets (Cooper, 2021).

Definition (Definition of the manifold ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M).

We define ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M to be the largest connected component of ∇F−1⁢(0)∇superscript𝐹10\nabla F^{-1}(0)∇ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) containing w∞GFsubscriptsuperscript𝑤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}_{\infty}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ∇F−1⁢(0)∇superscript𝐹10\nabla F^{-1}(0)∇ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) corresponds to the set of stationary points of F𝐹Fitalic_F.

Our key assumption is that ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M forms a smooth manifold, and that it contains only local minimizers (and not saddle points). Additionnally, we impose that the non-zero eigenvalues of the Hessian on ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M are lower bounded by some constant η>0𝜂0\eta>0italic_η > 0. Following the terminology of Rebjock and Boumal (2024), this is known as the Morse-Bott property.

Assumption 2.

ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M is a smooth submanifold of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of dimension k∈[d]𝑘delimited-[]𝑑k\in[d]italic_k ∈ [ italic_d ], i.e. for any w∈ℳ𝑤ℳw\in\mathcal{M}italic_w ∈ caligraphic_M, rank⁢(∇2F⁢(w))=d−kranksuperscript∇2𝐹𝑤𝑑𝑘\mathrm{rank}(\nabla^{2}F(w))=d-kroman_rank ( ∇ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_w ) ) = italic_d - italic_k. Also, there exists η>0𝜂0\eta>0italic_η > 0 such that for any w∈ℳ𝑤ℳw\in\mathcal{M}italic_w ∈ caligraphic_M, all non-zero eigenvalues of ∇2F⁢(w)superscript∇2𝐹𝑤\nabla^{2}F(w)∇ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_w ) are lower bounded by η𝜂\etaitalic_η.

As stated in Rebjock and Boumal (2024), for 𝒞2superscript𝒞2\mathcal{C}^{2}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT functions this property is equivalent to the Kurdyka–Łojasiewicz, also known as Polyak–Łojasiewicz (PL) condition locally around ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M (Kurdyka, 1998; Bolte et al., 2009). It implies that (i) every point in ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M is a local minimiser, and (ii) all gradient flow trajectories are locally attracted towards ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M. This stability property is essential for proving regularity of the flow map ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ in Section 4. Let us discuss the relevance of Assumption 2 in the context of overparameterised machine learning.

  • •

    Convergence to a local minimiser: our assumption rules out the possibility that wGFsuperscript𝑤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges to a saddle point of F𝐹Fitalic_F. This is justified by a large number of works showing that gradient methods avoid saddle points for almost all initialisations. In particular, Lee et al. (2016, 2019) prove it under the assumption that all saddle points of F𝐹Fitalic_F are strict. Although their result only holds for discrete-time gradient descent, the underlying argument can be extended to gradient flow (the proof relies on the Stable Manifold Theorem for dynamical systems, which also holds in continuous time (Teschl, 2012, §7)).

  • •

    Morse-Bott/Łojasiewicz property: this is a common assumption in the analysis of gradient flow dynamics for overparameterised networks (Li et al., 2021; Fatkullin et al., 2010; Shalova et al., 2024). Note that for general models, the critical set may not form a manifold everywhere. However, it is often possible to show that the manifold structure holds on most of the space, excluding some degenerate points; see Section 5 for examples and Liu et al. (2022a) for a generic result. Moreover, the results derived from such an assumption are generally very representative of empirical observations, as can be seen in Section 5.

Riemannian gradient flow on ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M.

We endow ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M with the standard Euclidean metric. For any differentiable function h:ℝd→ℝ:ℎ→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝh:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_h : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R, we denote by gradℳ⁢hsubscriptgradℳℎ\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}hroman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h the Riemannian gradient on ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M of the function hℎhitalic_h defined as follows:

gradℳ⁢h:ℳ→ℝdw↦PTℳ⁢(w)⁢(∇h⁢(w)),:subscriptgradℳℎ→ℳsuperscriptℝ𝑑maps-to𝑤subscript𝑃subscript𝑇ℳ𝑤∇ℎ𝑤\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}h:\begin{array}[]{l}\mathcal{M}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}\\ w\mapsto P_{T_{\mathcal{M}}(w)}(\nabla h(w)),\end{array}roman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h : start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_M → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_w ↦ italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ∇ italic_h ( italic_w ) ) , end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

where PTℳ⁢(w)subscript𝑃subscript𝑇ℳ𝑤P_{T_{\mathcal{M}}(w)}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the orthogonal projection on the tangent space to ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M at w𝑤witalic_w. Under Assumption 2, typical properties of smooth manifolds imply that Tℳ⁢(w)=Ker⁢(∇2F⁢(w))subscript𝑇ℳ𝑤Kersuperscript∇2𝐹𝑤T_{\mathcal{M}}(w)=\mathrm{Ker}(\nabla^{2}F(w))italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) = roman_Ker ( ∇ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_w ) ) (see e.g., Boumal, 2023, for a detailed introduction to optimisation on manifolds). Using this notion of Riemannian gradient, we study the Riemannian gradient flow for some objective function hℎhitalic_h and initialization wℳ∈ℳsubscript𝑤ℳℳw_{\mathcal{M}}\in\mathcal{M}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_M, defined as the curve w𝑤witalic_w satisfying,

w˙⁢(t)=−gradℳ⁢h⁢(w⁢(t)) and w⁢(0)=wℳ.formulae-sequence˙𝑤𝑡subscriptgradℳℎ𝑤𝑡 and 𝑤0subscript𝑤ℳ\dot{w}(t)=-\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}h(w(t))\quad\text{ and }\quad w(0)=w_{% \mathcal{M}}.over˙ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG ( italic_t ) = - roman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_w ( italic_t ) ) and italic_w ( 0 ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (3)

By construction of the Riemannian gradient, the trajectory of any solution of this ODE necessarily belongs to ∇F−1⁢(0)∇superscript𝐹10\nabla F^{-1}(0)∇ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ), and therefore to ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, since ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M is a maximal connected component. If hℎhitalic_h is 𝒞2superscript𝒞2\mathcal{C}^{2}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and has compact sublevel sets, Assumptions 1 and 2 guarantee that there exists a unique solution to Equation 3 and that it is defined on ℝ+subscriptℝ\mathbb{R}_{+}blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

4 Grokking as two-timescale dynamics

This section states our main results, where we characterise the two-timescale dynamics of the regularised gradient flow (1) in the limit λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\to 0italic_λ → 0. In Section 4.1 we describe the first phase, the fast dynamics, where wλsuperscript𝑤𝜆w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT approximates the unregularised gradient flow solution on finite time horizons. Section 4.2 then identifies the second, slow dynamics happening at arbitrarily large time horizons, where wλsuperscript𝑤𝜆w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT follows the Riemannian flow of the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm on the manifold ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M of stationary points.

4.1 Fast dynamics

A first simple observation is that as λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\to 0italic_λ → 0, Fλ→F→subscript𝐹𝜆𝐹F_{\lambda}\to Fitalic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → italic_F uniformly on any compact of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. From there, it seems natural that wλsuperscript𝑤𝜆w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT should converge, at least pointwise, to wGFsuperscript𝑤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\to 0italic_λ → 0. A Grönwall argument indeed allows to characterise the first, fast timescale dynamics given by Proposition 1 below.

Proposition 1.

If Assumption 1 holds, then for all T≥0𝑇0T\geq 0italic_T ≥ 0, wλ⁢⟶λ→0⁢wG⁢Fsuperscript𝑤𝜆→𝜆0⟶superscript𝑤𝐺𝐹w^{\lambda}\underset{\lambda\to 0}{\longrightarrow}w^{GF}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_UNDERACCENT italic_λ → 0 end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ⟶ end_ARG italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_G italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in (𝒞0([0,T],ℝd),∥⋅∥∞)(\mathcal{C}^{0}([0,T],\mathbb{R}^{d}),\|\cdot\|_{\infty})( caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ 0 , italic_T ] , blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )

Importantly, uniform convergence only holds on finite time intervals of the form [0,T]0𝑇[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ], but is not true on ℝ+subscriptℝ\mathbb{R}_{+}blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. More precisely, grokking is observed when the two limits cannot be exchanged: limλ→0+limt→∞wλ⁢(t)≠limt→∞limλ→0+wλ⁢(t)=limt→∞wGF⁢(t)subscript→𝜆superscript0subscript→𝑡superscript𝑤𝜆𝑡subscript→𝑡subscript→𝜆superscript0superscript𝑤𝜆𝑡subscript→𝑡superscript𝑤GF𝑡\lim_{\lambda\to 0^{+}}\lim_{t\to\infty}w^{\lambda}(t)\neq\lim_{t\to\infty}% \lim_{\lambda\to 0^{+}}w^{\lambda}(t)=\lim_{t\to\infty}w^{\mathrm{GF}}(t)roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ → 0 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ≠ roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ → 0 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ). In Figure 1, the endpoint of the red arrow corresponds to this first limit, while the endpoint of the blue arrow corresponds to the second. This distinction highlights a key aspect of grokking: the dynamics evolve on two different timescales. Initially, as described by Proposition 1, the regularised flow tracks the unregularised one. But at much larger time horizons, the regularised dynamics begin to diverge.

4.2 Slow dynamics

The second part of the dynamics is harder to capture, since it happens at a time approaching infinity, when λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ approaches zero. It is done using theory of singularly perturbed systems. In the following, we associate to the unregularised flow function a mapping ϕ:ℝd×ℝ+→ℝd:italic-ϕ→superscriptℝ𝑑subscriptℝsuperscriptℝ𝑑\phi:\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}_{+}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_ϕ : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfying

ϕ⁢(w,t)=ϕ⁢(w,0)−∫0t∇F⁢(ϕ⁢(w,s))⁢ds,∀(w,t)∈ℝd×ℝ+.formulae-sequenceitalic-ϕ𝑤𝑡italic-ϕ𝑤0superscriptsubscript0𝑡∇𝐹italic-ϕ𝑤𝑠differential-d𝑠for-all𝑤𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑subscriptℝ\phi(w,t)=\phi(w,0)-\int_{0}^{t}\nabla F(\phi(w,s))\ \mathrm{d}s,\qquad\forall% (w,t)\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}_{+}.italic_ϕ ( italic_w , italic_t ) = italic_ϕ ( italic_w , 0 ) - ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∇ italic_F ( italic_ϕ ( italic_w , italic_s ) ) roman_d italic_s , ∀ ( italic_w , italic_t ) ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Note that ϕ⁢(w,t)italic-ϕ𝑤𝑡\phi(w,t)italic_ϕ ( italic_w , italic_t ) simply corresponds to the solution of the gradient flow of Equation 2 at time t𝑡titalic_t when initialised in w𝑤witalic_w. When possible to define—i.e., when the gradient flow admits a limit point in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT—we define the mapping ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ as

Φ⁢(w)=limt→∞ϕ⁢(w,t).Φ𝑤subscript→𝑡italic-ϕ𝑤𝑡\Phi(w)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\phi(w,t).roman_Φ ( italic_w ) = roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ ( italic_w , italic_t ) . (4)

Thanks to Assumption 1, the unregularised flow initialised in w0subscript𝑤0w_{0}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT admits the limit point Φ⁢(w0)Φsubscript𝑤0\Phi(w_{0})roman_Φ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which is necessarily a stationary point of the loss, i.e., ∇F⁢(Φ⁢(w0))=0∇𝐹Φsubscript𝑤00\nabla F(\Phi(w_{0}))=0∇ italic_F ( roman_Φ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) = 0. Assumption 2 then ensure that the mapping ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ is defined and 𝒞2superscript𝒞2\mathcal{C}^{2}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on some neighbourhood of ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, thanks to a result of Falconer (1983).

Lemma 1.

If Assumptions 1 and 2 hold, there exists an open neighbourhood U𝑈Uitalic_U of ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M such that ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ is defined and 𝒞2superscript𝒞2\mathcal{C}^{2}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on U𝑈Uitalic_U.

Now the mapping ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ is well defined on a neighbourhood of ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, it can be used to describe the limit of the slow dynamics. For λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0italic_λ > 0, we let w~λ:t↦wλ⁢(t/λ):superscript~𝑤𝜆maps-to𝑡superscript𝑤𝜆𝑡𝜆\tilde{w}^{\lambda}:t\mapsto w^{\lambda}(t/\lambda)over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_t ↦ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t / italic_λ ). We indeed have to adequately “speed-up” time to capture its behaviour. Notably, w~λsuperscript~𝑤𝜆\tilde{w}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies the following differential equation:

w~˙λ⁢(t)=−w~λ⁢(t)−1λ⁢∇F⁢(w~λ⁢(t)) and w~λ⁢(0)=w0.formulae-sequencesuperscript˙~𝑤𝜆𝑡superscript~𝑤𝜆𝑡1𝜆∇𝐹superscript~𝑤𝜆𝑡 and superscript~𝑤𝜆0subscript𝑤0\begin{gathered}\dot{\tilde{w}}^{\lambda}(t)=-\tilde{w}^{\lambda}(t)-\frac{1}{% \lambda}\nabla F(\tilde{w}^{\lambda}(t))\quad\text{ and }\quad\tilde{w}^{% \lambda}(0)=w_{0}.\end{gathered}start_ROW start_CELL over˙ start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = - over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG ∇ italic_F ( over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) and over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW (5)

Our goal in this section is to study the limit function limλ→0w~λsubscript→𝜆0superscript~𝑤𝜆\lim_{\lambda\to 0}\tilde{w}^{\lambda}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ → 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Intuitively, the 1λ⁢∇F1𝜆∇𝐹\frac{1}{\lambda}\nabla Fdivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG ∇ italic_F term in Equation 5 will enforce this limit to stay on the stationary manifold ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M for any t>0𝑡0t>0italic_t > 0. The slow dynamics will be shown to approximate the Riemannian flow of the squared Euclidean norm on the stationary manifold ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M for t>0𝑡0t>0italic_t > 0. This limit flow is defined by w~∘superscript~𝑤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is the solution of the following differential equation on ℝ+subscriptℝ\mathbb{R}_{+}blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for the function ℓ2:w↦‖w‖22/2:subscriptℓ2maps-to𝑤superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑤222\ell_{2}:w\mapsto\|w\|_{2}^{2}/2roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_w ↦ ∥ italic_w ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / 2,

w~˙∘⁢(t)=−gradℳ⁢ℓ2⁢(w~∘⁢(t)) and w~∘⁢(0)=Φ⁢(w0).formulae-sequencesuperscript˙~𝑤𝑡subscriptgradℳsubscriptℓ2superscript~𝑤𝑡 and superscript~𝑤0Φsubscript𝑤0\dot{\tilde{w}}^{\circ}(t)=-\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}\ \ell_{2}(\tilde{w}^{% \circ}(t))\quad\text{ and }\quad\tilde{w}^{\circ}(0)=\Phi(w_{0}).over˙ start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = - roman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) and over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = roman_Φ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (6)

Recall that the Riemannian gradient is gradℳ⁢ℓ2⁢(w)=PKer⁢(∇2F⁢(w))⁢(w)subscriptgradℳsubscriptℓ2𝑤subscript𝑃Kersuperscript∇2𝐹𝑤𝑤\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}\ \ell_{2}(w)=P_{\mathrm{Ker}(\nabla^{2}F(w))}(w)roman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) = italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Ker ( ∇ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_w ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) for any w∈ℳ𝑤ℳw\in\mathcal{M}italic_w ∈ caligraphic_M. Denoting D⁢Φw𝐷subscriptΦ𝑤D\Phi_{w}italic_D roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the differential of ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ at w𝑤witalic_w, Li et al. (2021, Lemma 4.3) proved that for any w∈ℳ𝑤ℳw\in\mathcal{M}italic_w ∈ caligraphic_M, PKer⁢(∇2F⁢(w))=D⁢Φwsubscript𝑃Kersuperscript∇2𝐹𝑤𝐷subscriptΦ𝑤P_{\mathrm{Ker}(\nabla^{2}F(w))}=D\Phi_{w}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Ker ( ∇ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_w ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_D roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., the differential of ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ at w𝑤witalic_w is given by the orthogonal projection onto the kernel space of the Hessian of F𝐹Fitalic_F. In consequence, w~∘superscript~𝑤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT also satisfies the following differential equation:

w~˙∘⁢(t)=−D⁢Φw~∘⁢(t)⁢(w~∘⁢(t)) and w~∘⁢(0)=Φ⁢(w0).formulae-sequencesuperscript˙~𝑤𝑡𝐷subscriptΦsuperscript~𝑤𝑡superscript~𝑤𝑡 and superscript~𝑤0Φsubscript𝑤0\dot{\tilde{w}}^{\circ}(t)=-D\Phi_{\tilde{w}^{\circ}(t)}(\tilde{w}^{\circ}(t))% \quad\text{ and }\quad\tilde{w}^{\circ}(0)=\Phi(w_{0}).over˙ start_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = - italic_D roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) and over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = roman_Φ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

Using this alternative description of w~∘superscript~𝑤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we can now prove our main result, given by Proposition 2.

Proposition 2.

If Assumptions 1 and 2 hold, then for all T,ε>0𝑇𝜀0T,\varepsilon>0italic_T , italic_ε > 0, we have w~λ⁢⟶λ→0⁢w~∘superscript~𝑤𝜆→𝜆0⟶superscript~𝑤\tilde{w}^{\lambda}\underset{\lambda\to 0}{\longrightarrow}\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_UNDERACCENT italic_λ → 0 end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ⟶ end_ARG over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in (𝒞0([ε,T],ℝd),∥⋅∥∞)(\mathcal{C}^{0}([\varepsilon,T],\mathbb{R}^{d}),\|\cdot\|_{\infty})( caligraphic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ italic_ε , italic_T ] , blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where w~∘superscript~𝑤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the unique solution on ℝ+subscriptℝ\mathbb{R}_{+}blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the differential equation (6).

Proposition 2 states that the slow dynamics w~λsuperscript~𝑤𝜆\tilde{w}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges uniformly to w~∘superscript~𝑤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\to 0italic_λ → 0 on any compact interval of the form [ε,T]𝜀𝑇[\varepsilon,T][ italic_ε , italic_T ]. Note that excluding 00 from this interval (i.e., ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0italic_ε > 0) is necessary. Indeed, uniform convergence cannot happen on an interval of the form (0,T]0𝑇(0,T]( 0 , italic_T ], since w~λ⁢(0)=w0superscript~𝑤𝜆0subscript𝑤0\tilde{w}^{\lambda}(0)=w_{0}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0italic_λ > 0 and w~∘⁢(0)=Φ⁢(w0)superscript~𝑤0Φsubscript𝑤0\tilde{w}^{\circ}(0)=\Phi(w_{0})over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = roman_Φ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). In particular, Proposition 2 leads to pointwise convergence of w~λsuperscript~𝑤𝜆\tilde{w}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: we have

{limλ→0w~λ⁢(0)=w0,limλ→0w~λ⁢(t)=w~∘⁢(t)if ⁢t>0.casessubscript→𝜆0superscript~𝑤𝜆0subscript𝑤0otherwiseformulae-sequencesubscript→𝜆0superscript~𝑤𝜆𝑡superscript~𝑤𝑡if 𝑡0otherwise\begin{cases}\lim\limits_{\lambda\to 0}\tilde{w}^{\lambda}(0)=w_{0},\\ \lim\limits_{\lambda\to 0}\tilde{w}^{\lambda}(t)=\tilde{w}^{\circ}(t)\quad% \text{if }t>0.\end{cases}{ start_ROW start_CELL roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ → 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ → 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) if italic_t > 0 . end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW

This limit function limλ→0w~λsubscript→𝜆0superscript~𝑤𝜆\lim_{\lambda\to 0}\tilde{w}^{\lambda}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ → 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is non-continuous at 00. Indeed the whole fast dynamics, which follows the unregularised flow, happens at that 00 point in the limit λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\to 0italic_λ → 0. On the other hand, Proposition 2 describes the second phase of the dynamics, starting from the convergence point of the unregularized flow Φ⁢(w0)Φsubscript𝑤0\Phi(w_{0})roman_Φ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) – at the rescaled time 0+superscript00^{+}0 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT – and following the Riemannian flow on ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M.

Note that, once the junction between the slow and fast dynamics is carefully handled via Lemma 2 in Section A.2, Proposition 2 can be derived from Fatkullin et al. (2010, Theorem 2.2), which heavily relies on the technical result of Katzenberger (1990). However, for the sake of completeness and readability, we provide a concise and self-contained proof of Proposition 2, avoiding the use of heavyweight methods from Katzenberger (1990) and relying on weaker assumptions.

Sketch of proof.

We here provide a sketch of proof with the key arguments leading to Proposition 2. Its complete and detailed proof can be found in Section A.3. We first define the shifted slow dynamics v~λsuperscript~𝑣𝜆\tilde{v}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for any t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0italic_t ≥ 0 as v~λ⁢(t)=w~λ⁢(t+t⁢(λ))superscript~𝑣𝜆𝑡superscript~𝑤𝜆𝑡𝑡𝜆\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t)=\tilde{w}^{\lambda}(t+t(\lambda))over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t + italic_t ( italic_λ ) ), where t⁢(λ)𝑡𝜆t(\lambda)italic_t ( italic_λ ) is the “junction point” between the two dynamics given by Lemma 2 in Section A.2, and satisfies limλ→0t⁢(λ)=0subscript→𝜆0𝑡𝜆0\lim_{\lambda\rightarrow 0}t(\lambda)=0roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ → 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ( italic_λ ) = 0. Using Lemma 2, v~λsuperscript~𝑣𝜆\tilde{v}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT then follows the same differential equation as w~λsuperscript~𝑤𝜆\tilde{w}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with an initial condition now satisfying limλ→0v~λ⁢(0)=Φ⁢(w0)∈ℳsubscript→𝜆0superscript~𝑣𝜆0Φsubscript𝑤0ℳ\lim_{\lambda\to 0}\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(0)=\Phi(w_{0})\in\mathcal{M}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ → 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = roman_Φ ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_M. While the dynamics of v~λsuperscript~𝑣𝜆\tilde{v}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT might be hard to control as λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\to 0italic_λ → 0, it is easier to control the one of Φ⁢(v~λ)Φsuperscript~𝑣𝜆\Phi(\tilde{v}^{\lambda})roman_Φ ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Using the chain rule, we indeed have

Φ˙⁢(v~λ⁢(t))=−D⁢Φv~λ⁢(t)⋅(v~λ⁢(t)+1λ⁢∇F⁢(v~λ⁢(t))).˙Φsuperscript~𝑣𝜆𝑡⋅𝐷subscriptΦsuperscript~𝑣𝜆𝑡superscript~𝑣𝜆𝑡1𝜆∇𝐹superscript~𝑣𝜆𝑡\dot{\Phi}(\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t))=-D\Phi_{\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t)}\cdot\Big{(}% \tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t)+\frac{1}{\lambda}\nabla F(\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t))\Big{)}.over˙ start_ARG roman_Φ end_ARG ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) = - italic_D roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG ∇ italic_F ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) ) .

Then using the fact that for any w𝑤witalic_w in a neighbourhood of ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, D⁢Φ⁢(w)⋅∇F⁢(w)=0⋅𝐷Φ𝑤∇𝐹𝑤0D\Phi(w)\cdot\nabla F(w)=0italic_D roman_Φ ( italic_w ) ⋅ ∇ italic_F ( italic_w ) = 0 (Li et al., 2021, Lemma C.2), this directly rewrites as

Φ˙⁢(v~λ⁢(t))=−D⁢Φv~λ⁢(t)⋅v~λ⁢(t).˙Φsuperscript~𝑣𝜆𝑡⋅𝐷subscriptΦsuperscript~𝑣𝜆𝑡superscript~𝑣𝜆𝑡\dot{\Phi}(\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t))=-D\Phi_{\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t)}\cdot\tilde{% v}^{\lambda}(t).over˙ start_ARG roman_Φ end_ARG ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) = - italic_D roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) .

Now note that this resembles the differential equation satisfied by w~∘superscript~𝑤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The two differences being that (i) the initialisation points differ, but limλ→0v~λ⁢(0)=w~∘⁢(0)subscript→𝜆0superscript~𝑣𝜆0superscript~𝑤0\lim_{\lambda\to 0}\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(0)=\tilde{w}^{\circ}(0)roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ → 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) = over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ); (ii) the time derivative is on Φ⁢(v~λ)Φsuperscript~𝑣𝜆\Phi(\tilde{v}^{\lambda})roman_Φ ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) rather than v~λsuperscript~𝑣𝜆\tilde{v}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT directly. To handle the second point, v~λsuperscript~𝑣𝜆\tilde{v}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Φ⁢(v~λ)Φsuperscript~𝑣𝜆\Phi(\tilde{v}^{\lambda})roman_Φ ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) obviously converge to the same initialisation point as λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\to 0italic_λ → 0. One can then use stability of the manifold ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, thanks to Assumption 2, to show that supt∈[0,T]‖v~λ⁢(t)−Φ⁢(v~λ⁢(t))‖subscriptsupremum𝑡0𝑇normsuperscript~𝑣𝜆𝑡Φsuperscript~𝑣𝜆𝑡\sup_{t\in[0,T]}\|\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t)-\Phi(\tilde{v}^{\lambda}(t))\|roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ [ 0 , italic_T ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) - roman_Φ ( over~ start_ARG italic_v end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) ∥ converges to 00 as λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\to 0italic_λ → 0. This then allows to conclude. ∎

Characterizing the limit of the Riemannian flow.

By monotonicity of its norm, w~∘superscript~𝑤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is obviously bounded over time. Typical optimisation results then guarantee that the limit set of w~∘⁢(t)superscript~𝑤𝑡\tilde{w}^{\circ}(t)over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) as t→∞→𝑡t\to\inftyitalic_t → ∞ is contained in the set of critical points of the squared Euclidean norm on the manifold ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, given by the KKT points of the following constrained problem:

minw∈ℳ⁡‖w‖22.subscript𝑤ℳsuperscriptsubscriptnorm𝑤22\min_{w\in\mathcal{M}}\|w\|_{2}^{2}.roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w ∈ caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_w ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (7)

The notion of KKT points indeed extend to smooth manifolds (Bergmann and Herzog, 2019), so that under Assumption 2, the KKT points of Equation 7 are given by the points w⋆∈ℳsuperscript𝑤⋆ℳw^{\star}\in\mathcal{M}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_M satisfying gradℳ⁢ℓ2⁢(w⋆)=0subscriptgradℳsubscriptℓ2superscript𝑤⋆0\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}\ell_{2}(w^{\star})=0roman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0, where we recall gradℳ⁢ℓ2subscriptgradℳsubscriptℓ2\mathrm{grad}_{\mathcal{M}}\ell_{2}roman_grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the Riemannian gradient.

We are then able to show that wλsuperscript𝑤𝜆w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges towards the set of KKT points. Note that this does not follow from Proposition 2 alone, as we also need to show that trajectory of wλsuperscript𝑤𝜆w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT remains bounded independently of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ: we can prove this is true in our case.

Proposition 3.

If Assumptions 1 and 2 hold, then for any sequence (λk)k∈ℕsubscriptsubscript𝜆𝑘𝑘ℕ(\lambda_{k})_{k\in\mathbb{N}}( italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ∈ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that λk⁢→k→∞⁢0subscript𝜆𝑘→𝑘→0\lambda_{k}\underset{k\to\infty}{\rightarrow}0italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_UNDERACCENT italic_k → ∞ end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG → end_ARG 0, the limit points of (limt→∞wλk⁢(t))k∈ℕsubscriptsubscript→𝑡superscript𝑤subscript𝜆𝑘𝑡𝑘ℕ(\lim_{t\to\infty}w^{\lambda_{k}}(t))_{k\in\mathbb{N}}( roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ∈ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are included in the KKT points of Equation 7.

While Proposition 3 guarantees that wλsuperscript𝑤𝜆w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT gets arbitrarily close to KKT points of Equation 7 as λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ goes to 00, it does not imply that it has the same limit as w~∘superscript~𝑤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. It is however guaranteed with the additional assumption that w~∘⁢(t)superscript~𝑤𝑡\tilde{w}^{\circ}(t)over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) converges to a strict local minimum of the Euclidean norm on the manifold ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M.

Proposition 4.

Let Assumptions 1 and 2 hold and, assume additionally that w∘⁢(t)superscript𝑤𝑡w^{\circ}(t)italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) converges towards a strict local minimum w⋆superscript𝑤⋆w^{\star}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the constrained problem (7). Then limλ→0limt→∞wλ⁢(t)=w⋆subscript→𝜆0subscript→𝑡superscript𝑤𝜆𝑡superscript𝑤⋆\lim_{\lambda\to 0}\lim_{t\to\infty}w^{\lambda}(t)=w^{\star}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ → 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

When the slow limit dynamics on ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M converges towards a strict local minimum, Proposition 4 guarantees that, for small enough λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ, wλsuperscript𝑤𝜆w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT gets trapped in the vicinity of this local minimum as t→∞→𝑡t\to\inftyitalic_t → ∞, allowing us to get a perfect characterisation of limλ→0limt→∞wλ⁢(t)subscript→𝜆0subscript→𝑡superscript𝑤𝜆𝑡\lim_{\lambda\to 0}\lim_{t\to\infty}w^{\lambda}(t)roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ → 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ). In particular, this double limit corresponds to the limit of the slow dynamics w~∘superscript~𝑤\tilde{w}^{\circ}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, while the permuted limit (limt→∞limλ→0wλ⁢(t)subscript→𝑡subscript→𝜆0superscript𝑤𝜆𝑡\lim_{t\to\infty}\lim_{\lambda\to 0}w^{\lambda}(t)roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ → 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t )) corresponds to the limit of the fast dynamics wGFsuperscript𝑤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, thanks to Proposition 1.

Comparison with Lyu et al. (2023).

The work most closely related to ours is that of Lyu et al. (2023), which provides a theoretical characterization of the grokking phenomenon as a transition from the NTK regime—i.e., the unregularised flow initialised at large scales—to the rich regime, which typically converges to KKT points of Equation 7. However, their analysis does not offer a general optimisation-based perspective on the phenomenon and, in particular, does not account for the slow drift phase along the solution manifold, which we identify and characterise. Moreover, their setting is more restrictive: it assumes specific network architectures with homogeneous parameterisation and requires large initialisation scales. In contrast, our results hold outside the NTK regime and apply across a broader class of settings. In addition, their theoretical guarantees rely on taking the initialisation scale to infinity while simultaneously letting the regularisation strength tend to zero, with both rates polynomially coupled. Their analysis establishes that, for some sufficiently large time t~⁢(λ)~𝑡𝜆\tilde{t}(\lambda)over~ start_ARG italic_t end_ARG ( italic_λ ), the regularised flow wλsuperscript𝑤𝜆w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT approaches KKT points of Equation 7, but it does not provide guarantees about the asymptotic behavior beyond this time. By contrast, Proposition 3 characterises the limit points of the flow wλsuperscript𝑤𝜆w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, offering a stronger and more complete understanding of its long-term dynamics.

5 Examples and experiments

Linear regression.

Let F⁢(w)=‖X⁢w−y‖22𝐹𝑤superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑋𝑤𝑦22F(w)=\|Xw-y\|_{2}^{2}italic_F ( italic_w ) = ∥ italic_X italic_w - italic_y ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with X∈ℝn×d𝑋superscriptℝ𝑛𝑑X\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d}italic_X ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n × italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and assume that min⁡F=0𝐹0\min F=0roman_min italic_F = 0. The problem is convex and the set of critical points is the affine subspace ℳ={w:X⁢w=y}ℳconditional-set𝑤𝑋𝑤𝑦\mathcal{M}=\{w\,:\,Xw=y\}caligraphic_M = { italic_w : italic_X italic_w = italic_y }; Assumption 2 is satisfied globally.

It is well known that unregularised gradient flow wGFsuperscript𝑤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges to 𝒫ℳ⁢(w0)subscript𝒫ℳsubscript𝑤0\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{M}}(w_{0})caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the projection of the initial point on ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M. Then, since ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M is convex, the Riemannian flow on ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M necessarily converges to the minimal ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm solution w⋆=X+⁢ysuperscript𝑤⋆superscript𝑋𝑦w^{\star}=X^{+}yitalic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_y, where X+superscript𝑋X^{+}italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes the pseudo-inverse. Those two points are different (unless w0=0subscript𝑤00w_{0}=0italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0), which leads to grokking, as w⋆superscript𝑤⋆w^{\star}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is expected to have better generalization properties than 𝒫ℳ⁢(w0)subscript𝒫ℳsubscript𝑤0\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{M}}(w_{0})caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (Bartlett et al., 2020). In this setting, the trajectories of wλsuperscript𝑤𝜆w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be computed explicitly to illustrate the two-timescale dynamics; see Appendix C.

Matrix completion.

This is a prototypical non-convex problem which is amenable to theoretical analysis. The goal is to recover a matrix M⋆∈ℝn×msuperscript𝑀⋆superscriptℝ𝑛𝑚M^{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times m}italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n × italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is assumed to be low-rank, from a subset of observed entries in Ω⊂[n]×[m]Ωdelimited-[]𝑛delimited-[]𝑚\Omega\subset[n]\times[m]roman_Ω ⊂ [ italic_n ] × [ italic_m ], by solving

minU∈ℝn×r,V∈ℝm×r⁡F⁢(U,V)=∑(i,j)∈Ω((U⁢V⊤)i⁢j−Mi⁢j⋆)2,subscriptformulae-sequence𝑈superscriptℝ𝑛𝑟𝑉superscriptℝ𝑚𝑟𝐹𝑈𝑉subscript𝑖𝑗Ωsuperscriptsubscript𝑈superscript𝑉top𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑀⋆𝑖𝑗2\min_{U\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times r},V\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times r}}F(U,V)=\textstyle% \sum_{(i,j)\in\Omega}\left((UV^{\top})_{ij}-M^{\star}_{ij}\right)^{2},roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n × italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_V ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m × italic_r end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_U , italic_V ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i , italic_j ) ∈ roman_Ω end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ( italic_U italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (8)

where r𝑟ritalic_r is the target rank. If the rank of the ground truth M⋆superscript𝑀⋆M^{\star}italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is known, one can set r𝑟ritalic_r accordingly. However, the true rank is often unknown. An alternative approach is to use overparameterisation and choose r𝑟ritalic_r much higher than needed. Although in this case F𝐹Fitalic_F has many minimizers, our results indicate that the gradient flow trajectories (2) for small λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ tend to converge towards low-rank solutions.

More precisely, we analyse the extreme overparameterised setting when r=m+n𝑟𝑚𝑛r=m+nitalic_r = italic_m + italic_n. In Appendix C, we show that the set ℳ⋆superscriptℳ⋆\mathcal{M}^{\star}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of stationary points of F𝐹Fitalic_F which are nonsingular matrices forms a manifold. Provided that unregularised gradient flow converges to a nonsingular point, we can apply our results locally. These results state that, in the second, slow phase of the dynamics, the trajectories minimise ‖U‖F2+‖V‖F2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑈𝐹2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑉𝐹2\|U\|_{F}^{2}+\|V\|_{F}^{2}∥ italic_U ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ∥ italic_V ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on ℳ⋆superscriptℳ⋆\mathcal{M}^{\star}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Recall that for a given matrix M∈ℝn×m𝑀superscriptℝ𝑛𝑚M\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times m}italic_M ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n × italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have

‖M‖∗=minU⁢V⊤=M⁡12⁢(‖U‖F2+‖V‖F2),subscriptnorm𝑀subscript𝑈superscript𝑉top𝑀12superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑈𝐹2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑉𝐹2\|M\|_{*}=\min_{UV^{\top}=M}\frac{1}{2}(\|U\|_{F}^{2}+\|V\|_{F}^{2}),∥ italic_M ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_M end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( ∥ italic_U ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ∥ italic_V ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ,

where ‖M‖∗subscriptnorm𝑀\|M\|_{*}∥ italic_M ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the nuclear norm (Srebro et al., 2004, Lemma 1). Since minimising the nuclear norm promotes low-rank solutions, this indicates a drift toward low-rank matrices during the slow phase of the dynamics. In Appendix C, we study the more general class of matrix sensing problems and discuss an important technical subtlety: the set ℳ⋆superscriptℳ⋆\mathcal{M}^{\star}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT forms a manifold only after excluding degenerate points. Handling those singularities is highly non-trivial and remains an open direction for future work.

Figure 2 below empirically confirms this grokking for matrix completion. We here randomly generate a rank 3333 ground truth matrix M⋆∈ℝ20×20superscript𝑀⋆superscriptℝ2020M^{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{20\times 20}italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 20 × 20 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with non-zero singular values σ1⋆,σ2⋆,σ3⋆subscriptsuperscript𝜎⋆1subscriptsuperscript𝜎⋆2subscriptsuperscript𝜎⋆3\sigma^{\star}_{1},\sigma^{\star}_{2},\sigma^{\star}_{3}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We randomly sample 50% of the entries to define the observed entries ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω. We then perform gradient descent with weight decay parameter λ=10−3𝜆superscript103\lambda=10^{-3}italic_λ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and stepsize γ=10−2𝛾superscript102\gamma=10^{-2}italic_γ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on the loss F⁢(U,V)𝐹𝑈𝑉F(U,V)italic_F ( italic_U , italic_V ) defined in Equation 8 and where the weights U,V∈ℝ20×10𝑈𝑉superscriptℝ2010U,V\in\mathbb{R}^{20\times 10}italic_U , italic_V ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 20 × 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are initialised with i.i.d. standard Gaussian entries. We then track the training loss, the unmasked test loss ‖M⋆−U⁢V⊤‖Fsubscriptnormsuperscript𝑀⋆𝑈superscript𝑉top𝐹\|M^{\star}-UV^{\top}\|_{F}∥ italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_U italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the weight norms ‖w‖2=‖U‖F2+‖V‖F2superscriptnorm𝑤2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑈𝐹2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑉𝐹2\|w\|^{2}=\|U\|_{F}^{2}+\|V\|_{F}^{2}∥ italic_w ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∥ italic_U ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ∥ italic_V ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and singular values of the reconstruction matrix U⁢V⊤𝑈superscript𝑉topUV^{\top}italic_U italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Additional experimental details can be found in Section D.1.

Explaining the observed grokking phenomenon. At time t=0𝑡0t=0italic_t = 0, the weights are randomly initialised and the training loss is high. Initially, the regularised and unregularised weights follow the same trajectory, and the training loss quickly drops to zero: the regularised iterates converge to the same solution as the unregularised gradient flow. This early solution has a high norm, large singular values, and poor generalisation performance. As training continues, around time t=1/λ𝑡1𝜆t=1/\lambdaitalic_t = 1 / italic_λ, the weight norms begin to decrease. By t≈104𝑡superscript104t\approx 10^{4}italic_t ≈ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the parameters have drifted to a new solution that still achieves zero training loss but has a much lower norm and actually coincides with the low rank ground truth matrix M⋆superscript𝑀⋆M^{\star}italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Two-layer ReLU network.

Although our theoretical framework does not allow for non-smooth architectures such as ReLU networks, we illustrate in Figure 3 that similar grokking dynamics can be observed in this case. We train a two-layer ReLU network of the form fw⁢(x)=∑j=1muj⁢ReLU⁢(vj⁢x+bj),subscript𝑓𝑤𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚subscript𝑢𝑗ReLUsubscript𝑣𝑗𝑥subscript𝑏𝑗f_{w}(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{m}u_{j}\,\mathrm{ReLU}(v_{j}x+b_{j}),italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ReLU ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , with weights w=(u,v,b)𝑤𝑢𝑣𝑏w=(u,v,b)italic_w = ( italic_u , italic_v , italic_b ) where the outer layer is u∈ℝm𝑢superscriptℝ𝑚u\in\mathbb{R}^{m}italic_u ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the inner weight v∈ℝm𝑣superscriptℝ𝑚v\in\mathbb{R}^{m}italic_v ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and bias b∈ℝm𝑏superscriptℝ𝑚b\in\mathbb{R}^{m}italic_b ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The teacher function f𝑓fitalic_f is a sum of 3333 ReLUs and is represented in dotted light blue in Figure 3. We generate a training dataset of n=10𝑛10n=10italic_n = 10 points by sampling xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uniformly in [−2,2]22[-2,2][ - 2 , 2 ] and computing yi=f⁢(xi)subscript𝑦𝑖𝑓subscript𝑥𝑖y_{i}=f(x_{i})italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). These training points are shown as black crosses in Figure 3. We train the student network with m=100𝑚100m=100italic_m = 100 by minimising the squared loss F⁢(w)=12⁢n⁢∑i=1n(fw⁢(xi)−yi)2𝐹𝑤12𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑤subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖2F(w)=\tfrac{1}{2n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(f_{w}(x_{i})-y_{i}\right)^{2}italic_F ( italic_w ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT using gradient descent with weight decay λ=10−3𝜆superscript103\lambda=10^{-3}italic_λ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for T=106𝑇superscript106T=10^{6}italic_T = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iterations and small step size. The initial weights are independently sampled from a Gaussian of variance 4444. At each iteration, we record the train loss, the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm of the weights, as well as the test loss over a fixed test dataset (plotted Figure 3, left).

Explaining the observed grokking phenomenon. At time t1=0subscript𝑡10t_{1}=0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, the weights are randomly initialised and the training loss is high. By t2=1subscript𝑡21t_{2}=1italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, the training loss has dropped to nearly zero, and the iterates closely approximate the solution that would be obtained by unregularised gradient flow, this solution does not have a low norm and generalises poorly. Subsequently, around time t=1/λ𝑡1𝜆t=1/\lambdaitalic_t = 1 / italic_λ, the weight norms begin to decrease, and by t3≈105subscript𝑡3superscript105t_{3}\approx 10^{5}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≈ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, they have drifted to a zero training loss solution which has a much lower ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm and which generalises much better. Such solutions are believed to have a small number of "kinks" (Savarese et al., 2019; Parhi and Nowak, 2021; Boursier and Flammarion, 2023), as observed in Figure 3 (far right plot).

Diagonal Linear Networks.

We also study—both as an application of Theorem 1 and numerically—the architecture of diagonal neural networks in Appendices C and D.2, which serve as a toy problem for neural network training dynamics. In that case grokking promotes sparse estimators.

6 Conclusion

This work presents a rigorous and general optimisation-based description of the grokking phenomenon as a two-timescale process. In the fast initial phase, parameters evolve according to the unregularised flow until reaching a stationary manifold. In the slower second phase, they follow the Riemannian gradient flow of the norm constrained to this manifold. Grokking naturally emerges from a gradual simplicity bias: starting from a poorly generalising solution recovered by unregularised gradient flow, the slow phase driven by weight decay gradually simplifies the model by reducing its norm, ultimately leading to better generalisation.

While prior work has extensively analysed the first phase via the implicit bias of optimisation algorithms, the second phase—norm minimisation constrained to the interpolation manifold—has received little attention. Our framework highlights the critical role of this phase and motivates further study of optimisation dynamics on interpolation manifolds.

Large initialisations (NTK regime) are known to yield poor generalisation (Chizat et al., 2019; Liu et al., 2022c), while small initialisations (rich regime) can lead to slow convergence or convergence to suboptimal solutions for the training loss (Boursier and Flammarion, 2024a, b). Grokking may offer a desirable compromise, achieving fast convergence to an interpolating solution while retaining strong generalisation.

Lastly, our analysis focuses on regression settings with bounded dynamics. In classification tasks, by contrast, the stationary manifold lies “at infinity” once interpolation is achieved. Extending our approach to such settings remains an open and promising direction for future work, likely requiring techniques tailored to classification losses.

Acknowledgments and Disclosure of Funding

E. Boursier would like to extend special thanks to Ranko Lazic for his insightful discussions, which were instrumental in initiating this project. S. Pesme would like to thank P. Quinton for carefully reading the paper and providing valuable feedback. R. Dragomir is a chair holder from the Hi! Paris interdisciplinary research center composed of Institut Polytechnique de Paris (IP Paris) and HEC Paris.
