For W∈𝒰𝑊𝒰W\in\mathcal{U}italic_W ∈ caligraphic_U, W𝑊Witalic_W is invertible and we have W∈ℳ∗𝑊superscriptℳW\in\mathcal{M}^{*}italic_W ∈ caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if and only if 𝒜∗⁢(𝒜⁢(W⁢W⊤)−y)=0superscript𝒜𝒜𝑊superscript𝑊top𝑦0\mathcal{A}^{*}(\mathcal{A}(WW^{\top})-y)=0caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_A ( italic_W italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_y ) = 0. The function H⁢(W)=𝒜∗⁢(𝒜⁢(W⁢W⊤)−y)𝐻𝑊superscript𝒜𝒜𝑊superscript𝑊top𝑦H(W)=\mathcal{A}^{*}(\mathcal{A}(WW^{\top})-y)italic_H ( italic_W ) = caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_A ( italic_W italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_y ) is therefore a local defining function for ℳ∗superscriptℳ\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Its differential at W¯¯𝑊\overline{W}over¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG satisfies for U∈ℝn×n𝑈superscriptℝ𝑛𝑛U\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}italic_U ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n × italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

D⁢H⁢(W¯)⁢[U]=𝒜∗⁢A⁢(W¯⁢U⊤+U⁢W¯⊤).𝐷𝐻¯𝑊delimited-[]𝑈superscript𝒜𝐴¯𝑊superscript𝑈top𝑈superscript¯𝑊topDH(\overline{W})[U]=\mathcal{A}^{*}A(\overline{W}U^{\top}+U\overline{W}^{\top}).italic_D italic_H ( over¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG ) [ italic_U ] = caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A ( over¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG italic_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_U over¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) .

Since W¯¯𝑊\overline{W}over¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG is invertible, the map ϕ:U↦W¯⁢U⊤+U⁢W¯⊤:italic-ϕmaps-to𝑈¯𝑊superscript𝑈top𝑈superscript¯𝑊top\phi:U\mapsto\overline{W}U^{\top}+U\overline{W}^{\top}italic_ϕ : italic_U ↦ over¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG italic_U start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_U over¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a surjection from ℝn×nsuperscriptℝ𝑛𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n × italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT onto 𝕊nsuperscript𝕊𝑛\mathbb{S}^{n}blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: indeed, note that for any Z∈𝕊n𝑍superscript𝕊𝑛Z\in\mathbb{S}^{n}italic_Z ∈ blackboard_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have ϕ⁢(U)=Zitalic-ϕ𝑈𝑍\phi\left(U\right)=Zitalic_ϕ ( italic_U ) = italic_Z with U=12⁢Z⁢(W¯−1)⊤𝑈12𝑍superscriptsuperscript¯𝑊1topU=\frac{1}{2}Z(\overline{W}^{-1})^{\top}italic_U = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_Z ( over¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, the rank of D⁢H⁢(W¯)𝐷𝐻¯𝑊DH(\overline{W})italic_D italic_H ( over¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG ) is equal to the rank of 𝒜∗⁢𝒜superscript𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}^{*}\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_A for any W¯∈ℳ∗¯𝑊superscriptℳ\overline{W}\in\mathcal{M}^{*}over¯ start_ARG italic_W end_ARG ∈ caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which proves that ℳ∗superscriptℳ\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a smooth manifold. ∎

Dealing with singularities.

In the last two examples, the set ∇F−1⁢(0)∇superscript𝐹10\nabla F^{-1}(0)∇ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) has singular points, and so Assumption 2 does not hold globally. However, we showed that it holds on “most of the space”, as there exists a negligible set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S such that ℳ∗=∇F−1⁢(0)∖𝒮superscriptℳ∇superscript𝐹10𝒮\mathcal{M}^{*}=\nabla F^{-1}(0)\setminus\mathcal{S}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∇ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) ∖ caligraphic_S is a smooth manifold.

Our results can still be applied locally, assuming that the unregularised gradient flow wGFsuperscript𝑤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges to a point w∞GF∈ℳ∗subscriptsuperscript𝑤GFsuperscriptℳw^{\mathrm{GF}}_{\infty}\in\mathcal{M}^{*}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Indeed, in that case there exists a neighborhood 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U of w∞GFsubscriptsuperscript𝑤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}_{\infty}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that ∇F−1⁢(0)∩𝒰∇superscript𝐹10𝒰\nabla F^{-1}(0)\cap\mathcal{U}∇ italic_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) ∩ caligraphic_U is included in ℳ∗superscriptℳ\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, the Morse-Bott property holds in this neighborhood.

Consider then the Riemannian gradient flow w∘superscript𝑤w^{\circ}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm on ℳ∗superscriptℳ\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT initialized at w∞GFsubscriptsuperscript𝑤GFw^{\mathrm{GF}}_{\infty}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GF end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For any time horizon T𝑇Titalic_T such that the trajectory of w∘superscript𝑤w^{\circ}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT stays in 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U on the interval [0,T]0𝑇[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ], we can restrict our analysis to this local region, where our assumptions are satisfied. We can then invoke Proposition 2 to conclude that w~λsuperscript~𝑤𝜆\tilde{w}^{\lambda}over~ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges to w∘superscript𝑤w^{\circ}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT uniformly on intervals of the form [ϵ,T]italic-ϵ𝑇[\epsilon,T][ italic_ϵ , italic_T ].

However, a key limitation arises when analyzing the long-time behavior: the results characterizing the limit points ( Proposition 4) do not apply if w∘superscript𝑤w^{\circ}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∘ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges to a singular point outside ℳ∗superscriptℳ\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This situation can occur, as singular points might correspond to points that minimize the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm on ℳ∗superscriptℳ\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (e.g., sparse vectors for diagonal networks, or low-rank matrices for matrix sensing). Establishing convergence of wλsuperscript𝑤𝜆w^{\lambda}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to such singular points remains an open and challenging problem, which we leave for future work.

In summary, our results capture the grokking dynamics near nonsingular points in ℳ∗superscriptℳ\mathcal{M}^{*}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, but do not yet account for potential convergence toward singular points, which represents an important open challenge.

Appendix D Additional experiments

D.1 Additional Experimental Details

In all our figures and to align with the continuous-time analysis, training iterations refers to the rescaled "training time" tk=γ⁢ksubscript𝑡𝑘𝛾𝑘t_{k}=\gamma kitalic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_γ italic_k, where k𝑘kitalic_k is the number of gradient steps and γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ the gradient descent stepsize. We run gradient descent 107superscript10710^{7}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iterations for Figure 2 and 106superscript10610^{6}10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iterations for Figure 3.

D.2 Diagonal linear networks.

Experimental setup (Figure 4). We train a two-layer diagonal linear network of the form fw⁢(x)=⟨u⊙v,φ⁢(x)⟩subscript𝑓𝑤𝑥direct-product𝑢𝑣𝜑𝑥f_{w}(x)=\langle u\odot v,\varphi(x)\rangleitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ⟨ italic_u ⊙ italic_v , italic_φ ( italic_x ) ⟩, where w=(u,v)∈ℝ2⁢d𝑤𝑢𝑣superscriptℝ2𝑑w=(u,v)\in\mathbb{R}^{2d}italic_w = ( italic_u , italic_v ) ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ⊙direct-product\odot⊙ denotes element-wise multiplication, on a 1D toy dataset. The input x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}italic_x ∈ blackboard_R is mapped to a high-dimensional feature space via the feature map φ⁢(x)=[1,cos⁡(π⁢x2),…,cos⁡(π⁢df⁢x2),sin⁡(π⁢x2),…,sin⁡(π⁢df⁢x2)],𝜑𝑥1𝜋𝑥2…𝜋subscript𝑑𝑓𝑥2𝜋𝑥2…𝜋subscript𝑑𝑓𝑥2\varphi(x)=\left[1,\cos\left(\tfrac{\pi x}{2}\right),\dots,\cos\left(\tfrac{% \pi d_{f}x}{2}\right),\sin\left(\tfrac{\pi x}{2}\right),\dots,\sin\left(\tfrac% {\pi d_{f}x}{2}\right)\right],italic_φ ( italic_x ) = [ 1 , roman_cos ( divide start_ARG italic_π italic_x end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) , … , roman_cos ( divide start_ARG italic_π italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) , roman_sin ( divide start_ARG italic_π italic_x end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) , … , roman_sin ( divide start_ARG italic_π italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) ] , with df=30subscript𝑑𝑓30d_{f}=30italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 30. The teacher function is a sparse Fourier series f⁢(x)=1+cos⁡(6⁢π⁢x2)+sin⁡(21⁢π⁢x2)𝑓𝑥16𝜋𝑥221𝜋𝑥2f(x)=1+\cos\left(\tfrac{6\pi x}{2}\right)+\sin\left(\tfrac{21\pi x}{2}\right)italic_f ( italic_x ) = 1 + roman_cos ( divide start_ARG 6 italic_π italic_x end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) + roman_sin ( divide start_ARG 21 italic_π italic_x end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) and is shown as a dotted light blue curve in Figure 4. The training dataset consists of n=12𝑛12n=12italic_n = 12 input-output pairs (xi,yi)subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖(x_{i},y_{i})( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are sampled uniformly in [−1,1]11[-1,1][ - 1 , 1 ] and yi=f⁢(xi)subscript𝑦𝑖𝑓subscript𝑥𝑖y_{i}=f(x_{i})italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). These training points are shown as crosses in Figure 4. We optimise the squared loss F⁢(w)=12⁢n⁢∑i=1n(yi−fw⁢(xi))2𝐹𝑤12𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑓𝑤subscript𝑥𝑖2F(w)=\tfrac{1}{2n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(y_{i}-f_{w}(x_{i})\right)^{2}italic_F ( italic_w ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_n end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT using gradient descent with weight decay λ=10−4𝜆superscript104\lambda=10^{-4}italic_λ = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Finally, the initial weights are sampled from a centered Gaussian of variance 0.10.10.10.1.

Explaining the observed grokking phenomenon. At time t1=0subscript𝑡10t_{1}=0italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, the weights are randomly initialised and the training loss is high. By t2=102subscript𝑡2superscript102t_{2}=10^{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the training loss has dropped to nearly zero, and the iterates closely approximate the solution that would be obtained by unregularised gradient flow. This solution is fully characterised by the implicit regularisation result of [Woodworth et al., 2020], and it does not have a low norm.444One could also reach the solution observed at time t3=105subscript𝑡3superscript105t_{3}=10^{5}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT without using weight decay by employing a much smaller initialisation scale Woodworth et al. [2020], but at the cost of longer training time. Subsequently, around time t=1/λ𝑡1𝜆t=1/\lambdaitalic_t = 1 / italic_λ, the weight norms begin to decrease, and by t3≈105subscript𝑡3superscript105t_{3}\approx 10^{5}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≈ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, they converge to the minimum-norm solution (u⋆,v⋆)=arg⁡minF⁢(u,v)=0⁡‖u‖22+‖v‖22superscript𝑢⋆superscript𝑣⋆subscript𝐹𝑢𝑣0superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑢22superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑣22(u^{\star},v^{\star})=\arg\min_{F(u,v)=0}\|u\|_{2}^{2}+\|v\|_{2}^{2}( italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ( italic_u , italic_v ) = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_u ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ∥ italic_v ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A straightforward calculation shows that the elementwise product β⋆≔u⋆⊙v⋆≔superscript𝛽⋆direct-productsuperscript𝑢⋆superscript𝑣⋆\beta^{\star}\coloneqq u^{\star}\odot v^{\star}italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≔ italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊙ italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋆ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT solves the problem arg⁡min⟨β,xi⟩=yi⁢∀i⁡‖β‖1subscript𝛽subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖for-all𝑖subscriptnorm𝛽1\arg\min_{\langle\beta,x_{i}\rangle=y_{i}\forall i}\|\beta\|_{1}roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟨ italic_β , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ = italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∀ italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_β ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is an ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-minimisation problem, which (under RIP conditions) is known to recover the sparsest solution [Candes, 2008], explaining the zero test loss after the grokking phenomenon.
